w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach vocabulary words associated with problem solving and feelings. They will learn these words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: problem, solution, feelings, I can, and I feel
At the completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce these target words associated with problem solving and feelings
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use these sets of words in complete sentences
Students will be able to describe their problems, solutions, and feelings
problem, solution, feelings, I can, and I feel
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about problems, solutions, and feelings.”
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the target word “
Ask the students: “What is a problem?”
: A challenge, usually unwelcome, which has to be overcome
Give students an example of a problem from your own experience.
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students circle the target word “
Ask the students: “What is a solution?”
Explain to the students what a solution is
: The means of overcoming the challenges presented by a problem.
Give students an example of a solution from your experience.
“The man is being chased by a dog.”
Circle the word problem on the slide
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Have the students describe what is happening in the
Ask the students: “What is the problem in this picture?”
Ask the students: “Why is this a problem? Why do you think the dog is chasing the man? What do you think could happen?”
Student can describe or circle possible solutions, i.e. “run faster, go inside, give the dog a treat”
Student can respond to prompts describing possible solutions, i.e. “run faster”
Answer the teacher’s questions in complete sentences.
Attempt to engage the student in conversation about possible solutions
such as “Could the man RUN FASTER as a solution?”
Students may have varying degrees of fluency/responses: The goal is to draw out the conversation

Explain to the students that happiness is an emotion and a feeling.
Ask the students: “How can you tell that the girl is happy?”
Ask the students: “When do you feel happy? What makes you happy?”
